title: Mosaics in Syria, Lebanon, and Palestine also depict women with their heads uncovered, so it is clear that not all women in the eastern provinces went about veiled. MacMullen plausibly resolves the conflict in the evidence by suggesting that in Italy Romanized women of all classes generally went about with uncovered heads. But in the eastern provinces only the wealthier, more "modern" women who were adopting the new Roman ways went bare-headed; the more conservative women of the humbler classes went veiled
